Graphical abstract A skeletal reaction scheme for NH3-SCR of NO over Ce doped-γFe2O3 catalyst (the red Ea represents the activation reaction barrier on Fe2 (or Fe3) sites while the blue Ea represents that on Fe1 (or Ce) sites). The doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3 catalyst surface can improve the NO removal catalytic activity and widen the temperature window of activity. However, the mechanism of promoting the De-NOx activity of γ-Fe2O3 catalyst by Ce doping has not been revealed. In this paper, therefore, the doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3(001) surface and the adsorption behavior of NH3 and NO as well as the reaction pathway were studied by the density functional theory (DFT). The results show that the doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3(001) surface can lead to the migration of electrons on the surface of catalyst and cause the dislocation of the surface lattice, so as to improve the surface acid activity. Thus, the Ce doping can increase the adsorbed energy of the modified γ-Fe2O3 catalyst to NO and NH3 and decrease the activation energy barrier of the rate determining step in SCR reaction. Furthermore, the effects of Ce doping will change with the concentration of the Ce doping, and the excellent SCR De-NOx efficiency will be obtained in the optimal doping amount. On the other hand, O2 makes an important effect. Which makes the activation energy barrier of the rate determining step under aerobic condition lower than that under anaerobic conditions, causes the surface active O to react with NO to form NO2 and perform a rapid SCR reaction. The Ce doping can promote the dissociation of O2 on the active cation site and reduce the activation energy barriers of above steps. Accordingly, the doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3 catalyst surface can improve the SCR process. Keywords γFe2O3 DFT SCR NOxRemoval Ce doping Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NOx), which will cause many problems is one of the main air pollutants [1–3]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR), with the high catalytic efficiency of more than 90 %, is the most widely used NOx removal technology in the industry nowadays [4]. SCR technology is based on the principle that NOx in flue gas reacts with NH3 or urea under the effects of catalysts to generate harmless N2 and H2O, and the main reaction equation is 4 N H 3 + 4 N O + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O [5–7]. In the reaction process, catalyst plays a key role and is the core of the technology. At present, the commercial catalyst is V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, whose active temperature window is 330−450℃, and it is easy to cause the wear, blockage, poisoning and deactivation of the catalyst [8]. Therefore, the low temperature nontoxic catalyst has become a new research hotspot. Due to the wide source, low price and wide active temperature window, Fe-based catalysts have attracted many researchers. The main component of Fe-based SCR NOx removal catalyst is iron oxide. The oxidation state of iron is mainly +2 valence iron oxide and +3 valence iron oxide, and iron oxides mainly include FeO, Fe3O4, α-Fe2O3 and γ-Fe2O3. Some scholars have shown that Fe2O3 has high SCR NOx removal activity [9,10]. Ramis et al. [11,12] prepared Fe2O3/TiO2 catalyst with TiO2 as support by impregnation method. It was found that Lewis acid site existed on the surface of the catalyst, which was beneficial to the SCR NOx removal reaction. Ma et al. [13] produced Fe2(SO4)3/TiO2 catalyst by impregnation method, the NOx removal efficiency was up to 98 % in the range of 350℃∼ 450℃, and the catalyst characterization results showed that the catalyst surface was mainly α-Fe2O3 and sulfate. Apostolescu [14] et al. developed α-Fe2O3 catalyst by polyvinyl alcohol method, and modified the surface of the catalyst with ammonium sulfate and ammonium phosphate. However, due to the small specific surface area, the highest NOx conversion rate was 61 %. Yao et al. [15,16] studied the flue gas de-NOx characteristics of γ-Fe2O3 in the fluidized bed, and found that γ-Fe2O3 showed good NOx removal efficiency in the low temperature range of 200 ∼ 290℃, and the highest efficiency was 90 % at 250℃. Yang et al. [17,18] found that the NOx removal efficiency of γ-Fe2O3 was higher than that of α-Fe2O3 through experiments, and pointed out that γ-Fe2O3 would change to α-Fe2O3 when it was higher than 300℃, resulting in the decrease of efficiency. Liang et al. [19] carried out experiments with nano-γFe2O3 particles as catalyst, and showed that NOx removal efficiency with nano-γFe2O3 is stable higher than 93 % in the temperature range of 150−330℃. Compared with vanadium based catalysts, Fe-based catalysts expand the NOx removal temperature window, but the iron oxide catalysts usually have the problems of poor low temperature catalytic activity, and poor sulfur resistance and water resistance, so it is necessary to dope other transition metal elements to modify the catalysts. CeO2 has a good ability of oxygen storage and release. The addition of Ce can improve the concentration of oxygen on the catalyst surface and the thermal stability of the support, and effectively inhibit the sulfation of the active components of the catalyst. Qi et al. [20] used Ce element to dope and modify manganese based composite oxides. The results showed that the MnOx-CeO2 catalyst produced by coprecipitation method had excellent SCR activity at low temperature. Wei et al. [21] prepared the Mn based catalyst modified by Ce doping by coprecipitation method and studied the effect of activity, the results showed that the catalyst had more than 90 % NOx removal efficiency in the temperature range of 180−300℃. Wu [22] developed Ce doped Mn/TiO2 catalysts by sol-gel method, it was found that the catalyst had a catalytic NOx removal efficiency of more than 95 % when the reaction temperature is 150 ℃. France et al. [23] prepared FeMnOx catalyst doped with CeO2 by citric acid method, and found that the surface of catalyst doped with Ce had more chemisorption of oxygen, which was conducive to the rapid SCR reaction. These experiments show that Ce has good catalytic NOx removal activity, and can produce synergistic effect with Fe. Therefore, doping of Ce in iron-based catalyst is beneficial to improve its SCR activity. It is necessary to explore the mechanism of the SCR of NO process on the Ce doped Fe-based catalyst surface to develop low temperature catalyst. But the few related researches were reported. Chen et al. [24] characterized the Ce doping calcined siderite catalyst with XRD and NH3-TPD method. The results showed that the doping of Ce could enhance the acidity of the adsorption site of the catalyst, so the catalytic activity of the modified siderite catalyst was improved by Ce doping. Since the basic composition of calcined siderite is Fe2O3, this result is helpful to understand the mechanism of Ce doping to improve the activity of Fe-based catalysts. However, it is still not clear how the doping of Ce can enhance the acidity of the adsorption site of the catalyst, and affects the NOx removal activity of Fe-based catalyst in the SCR. Therefore, microscopic theoretical tools should be used for further research so as to reveal the mechanism of doping Ce to promote the SCR activity of Fe-based catalyst from a micro perspective. Because quantum chemistry and DFT have the powerful function of detecting micro chemical reaction mechanism in molecular scale, more and more scholars use DFT to study the mechanism of SCR process [25–30]. On the other hand, as the first step in the SCR NOx removal, the adsorption of NH3 and NOx on the surface is very important on the exploring the mechanism of the SCR of NO. Hence, many authors have studied adsorption behavior of molecules on the catalyst surface by DFT. Liu et al. [31] studied the adsorption of NOx on the Ga doped Al2O3 crystal surface by the DMol3 method of density functional theory. It was found that the activity of Al2O3 (110) surface was better than that of Al2O3 (100), and NO was more easily adsorbed on AlⅢ site of Al2O3 (110). Song et al. [32] studied the adsorption of H2O2 and NO on the Ti-doped Fe3O4(001) surfaces by DFT. The result showed that Ti doping could promote the adsorption and decomposition of H2O2 on the catalyst surface. However, NO and NH3 adsorption mechanism research by DFT on the Fe based catalysts doped with Ce has almost not been reported. This affects the understanding of the mechanism of the effects of Ce doping on SCR of NO of catalysts, and hinders the development of Ce doped iron-based catalysts. In this paper, the mechanism of adsorption of NH3 and NOx on the surface of Ce doped γ-Fe2O3 NOx removal catalyst was studied with DFT, and the effect of Ce doping on SCR process was explored. Computational methods and model In this paper, the model of γ-Fe2O3 as catalyst was established and the supercell is shown in Fig. 1 . The γ-Fe2O3 catalyst had a spinel-type structure and it had a cubic unit cell with 32 O2 and 21.33 FeⅢ each cell, and the lattice constant is 0.834 nm. The space grope is Fd3m and the formula is Fe21.33O32 [33]. In the cell, Feoct and Fetet means the octahedral and tetrahedral sites which coexisted. In the research process, the first step was to optimize the unit cell and then the reaction surface was selected. The (001) surface had the strongest reactivity and it is a most table surface [34,35], so the (001) surface was selected and a set of supercell periodic plate model (1 × 1) and (2 × 1) with 3 atomic layers were established, and the (001) surface is shown in Fig. 2 . In the process, the DMol3 package was used to perform the calculations, and spin-polarized DFT model was used. Furthermore, the GGA method was set to the electron exchange correlation function [36–38], as well as the effective core potentials (ECP) method was implemented for core electrons of Fe and Ce atoms [39]. During calculations, the double-numeric quality plus polarization (DNP) functions were employed on all atoms, and a real space cutoff radius of 5.0 Å was selected [40]. For the adsorption and reaction system, the Brillouin zone was integrated using 5 × 5×1 Monkhorst–Pack grids. The adsorption energy was evaluated to characterize the adsorption properties of catalysts. And the adsorption energy was defined as follows: (1) E a d s = E s l a b + m o l e c u l e − E s l a b − E m o l e c u l e Where, E a d s means the adsorption energy, E s l a b + m o l e c u l e means the energy of slab and molecule after adsorption, E s l a b and E m o l e c u l e are the energy of the catalyst slab before adsorption and that of NH3 and NO molecule before adsorption, respectively. The doping energies ( E d o p ) of Ce/Mn-doped γ-Fe2O3 surfaces was calculated using the following equation: (2) E d o p = E C e − γ F e 2 O 3 + μ F e − E γ F e 2 O 3 − μ C e Where, E d o p is the doping energies of Ce-doped on γ-Fe2O3 surfaces, E C e − γ F e 2 O 3 means the energies of Ce/Mn-doped γ-Fe2O3 slab, and E γ F e 2 O 3 means the energy of γ-Fe2O3 surfaces without dope, μ F e and μ C e are the chemical potentials of iron, cerium respectively. The NH3-SCR process over Ce doped γ-Fe2O3 catalyst had different steps and with different intermediate products (IM), transition states (TS) and final states (FS). On the calculation process, the LST-QST method was employed to search the transition states (TS), and the vibration frequency was analyzed to ensure that it had only one virtual frequency [41]. The activation energy barrier (Ea) is defined as the following equation [42,43]: (3) Ea = ETS − EIM where ETS is intermediate energy and EIM represents the transition state energy. Results and discussion The doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3 surfaces To improve the catalytic activity of the γ-Fe2O3 catalyst, it is necessary to dope the catalyst. Ce elements have good NOx removal performance, so there are often used to modify catalyst. In order to study the influence of different doping concentrations, 1 × 1 and 2 × 1 surfaces were selected for doping calculation. And the 1 × 1 and 2 × 1 surface are shown on Fig. 3 . The doping energies are calculated to indicate the strength of the link between atoms after doping and the difficulty of the forming process. Fig. 4 shows the configuration of Ce doping 1 × 1 and 2 × 1 surfaces respectively. In the 1 × 1 lattice represented by Fig. 6(a), one of the two octahedral Fe cations on the surface is replaced by Ce cation, and in the 2 × 1 lattice represented by Fig. 6(b), one of the four octahedral Fe ions on the surface is replaced by Ce cation. Since the phase structure of the catalyst represented by the XRD patterns does not change obviously before and after Ce doping, it can be considered that the doping of Ce does not change the crystal structure of the Fe2O3 catalyst, and only replaces the Fe cation of the catalyst. Hence the model is consistent with the actual situation [24]. Because the atomic radius of Ce is much larger than that of Fe, the doping of Ce will cause the dislocation and change of the surface lattice parameter. The Ce doping energy is -389.023 kJ/mol, which means the process of Ce doping is exothermic and Ce and Fe will form stable composite oxides. On the 1 × 1 γ-Fe2O3 surface, the Fe-O bond on the surface is 1.921 Å, and after doping, the Fe-O bond left is 1.906 Å and the Ce-O bond is 2.178 Å. It can be seen that the length of Ce-O bond is larger than that of Fe-O, and the length of Fe-O will be reduced due to the influence of Ce. It shows that the doping of Ce will lead to the displacement of the surface lattice, which will affect the performance of the catalyst. The Mulliken charge of surface octahedral Fe cation changes -0.094 a.u, which means that there are 0.094e electrons transferred from Ce cation to Fe cation. This is because the electronegativity of Fe is more than that of Ce, and the electron is attracted by Fe cation. Hence, the Ce doping brings more valence electrons, as well as the surface free electrons increased so as to change the redox ability of the surface. On the 2 × 1 γ-Fe2O3 surface, the lattice parameter can also be changed because of the Ce doping. The Ce-O bond length is 2.182 Å, and the Fe1-O, Fe2-O, Fe3-O bond length are 1.910 Å, 1.919 Å, and 1.916 Å, respectively. Furthermore, the Mulliken charge change of Fe1, Fe2, Fe3 are -0.079 a.u, -0.030 a.u, and -0.031 a.u, separately. This means that the doping of Ce also causes the decrease of the Fe-O bond length, which is determined by the fact that the atomic radius of Ce is larger than that of Fe and the Ce-O bond length is larger than the Fe-O bond length. Moreover, the farther the three Fe cations are away from Ce, the smaller the effect is and the longer the bond is. Compared with the surface of 1 × 1, the Ce-O bond and the Fe-O bond are both longer on the surface of 2 × 1, which is caused by the different doping concentration of Ce. The change of Mullien charge shows that on the doping process, the Fe cations obtain electrons from Ce and the Fe1 which closest to Ce may get more than others, and the Fe2, Fe3 get almost the same because they far away from Ce cation. The adsorption of NH3 on Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface On the SCR process, the NH3 and NO as reactants can be absorbed firstly on the surface of γ-Fe2O3 catalyst before Ce doping, and has a great influence on the NOx removal efficiency. Hence, the adsorption of NH3 and NO on γ-Fe2O3 surfaces before Ce doping is considered firstly. In the process of adsorption, the N atom of NH3 binds to the octahedral Fe cation on the surface, and the adsorption energy is -104.786 kJ/mol. A small number of electrons transfer from the NH3 molecule to substrate since the Mulliken charge change of the NH3 molecule is 0.247 a.u, and a stable chemical bond forms between N atom and Fe cation. In addition, the NH bond angle is 113.825° which means the bond angle increasing with the lose of electrons. In order to study the effect of Ce doping on the NOx removal efficiency of the catalyst, it is necessary to study the effect of Ce doping on the adsorption of NH3 and NO. Fig. 5 shows the NH3 adsorption configuration on 1 × 1 Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface and the parameters are list in Table 1 . It can be seen that the metal cation as main acid can absorb the NH3 molecule. On the Fig. 5(a) configuration, the N atom of NH3 combined with Ce cation, and the N atom bond to Fe cation on the Fig. 5(b) configuration. The adsorption energies of these two configurations are -66.441 kJ/mol and -44.045 kJ/mol respectively. Compared with the adsorption energy on the undoped Fe based catalysts, the adsorption energy decreases. The Mulliken charges of NH3 are 0.140 a.u and 0.185 a.u respectively, which means that less electrons are transferred in the process because of the increase of the number of active site electrons due to the doping of Ce. Accordingly, the bond angle of NH3 decreases compared to the situation without doping Ce because of less electrons transferred, and the bond length of Fe-N and Ce-N shorten. Thus it is harder to form stable chemical bond between N atom and metal matrix element, and the adsorption energy decreases. Therefore, the doping of Ce on the 1 × 1 surface of γ-Fe2O3 restrains the adsorption of NH3. Fig. 6 shows the adsorption of NH3 on Ce doping 2 × 1 γ-Fe2O3 surface. On Fig. 6(a) configuration, the N atom of NH3 bonds to Ce cation, and the N atom bonds to Fe1 on Fig. 6(b), Fe2 on Fig. 9(c), and Fe3 on Fig. 9(d), respectively. The corresponding optimized parameters are listed in Table 2 . The adsorption energies are -138.456 kJ/mol, -129.778 kJ/mol, -167.399 kJ/mol and -165.753 kJ/mol, individually. It is obvious that the adsorption energy of NH3 on the 2 × 1Ce doped γ-Fe2O3 surface has been improved. Among them, the adsorption energy at Fe2 site is the largest, Fe3 is smaller slightly, and Fe1 is the smallest. On the other hand, NH3 transfers the most electrons of 0.245e when adsorbed on Fe2 site. Moreover, 0.242e electrons are transferred when it is adsorbed on Fe3, and 0.189e are transferred when it is adsorbed on Fe1, which is much smaller than that on Fe2 and Fe3. This is because Fe1 is closer to Ce than Fe2 and Fe3. Therefore, Fe1 has already got some electrons from Ce caution in the process of doping, only fewer electrons can be further received from NH3. As Fe3 has got fewer electrons, it can accept more ones. The N-Fe bond lengths of three iron atoms are arranged as Fe1 > Fe3 > Fe2, while the bond angles of NH3 are arranged as Fe2 > Fe3 > Fe1. It can be seen that in the three configurations, the more transferred electrons, the larger bond angle, the shorter N-Fe bond, the greater adsorption energy and the more stable configuration. Hence, it can be concluded that the doping of Ce will cause the surface electron migration, which will change the surface acidity and affect its NH3 adsorption capacity. This is because Ce and Fe are different kinds of metal cations. The adsorption capacity to link N anions is not only related to the number of transferred electrons, but also to the distribution of electron cloud outside the nucleus. Under the same number of transferred electrons, the adsorption capacity of Ce is larger than that of Fe, so that the adsorption energy of substrate which doping Ce is large. In order to explore the mechanism of bond of NH3 on Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface, it is necessary to analyze the PDOS (partial density of state) of adsorption process. The Fig. 7 (a) and (b) show the PDOS of NH3 molecule adsorbed on the Ce cation of surface and that on the Fe2 cation, respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 7(b) that the p orbital of NH3 overlaps with the d orbitals of Fe at −6 eV and -5 eV, thereby demonstrating that orbital hybridization occurred between NH3 and Fe. The bonding mechanism for the Ce caution and NH3 is roughly the same as shown in Fig. 7(a). Therefore, the influence of Ce on adsorption energy is mainly caused by the migration of surface electrons and lattice dislocation. In order to further explore the influence of different Ce doping concentration on the adsorption performance, the surface of 3 × 1 of Ce doped was selected, the configuration is shown in Fig. 8 . In this configuration, one of the six octahedral Fe cations on the surface is replaced by Ce, and the NH3 molecule can be adsorbed on the left Fe cations. And the adsorption energy in turn are -93.251 kJ/mol, -107.781 kJ/mol, -107.022 kJ/mol, -107.459 kJ/mol, and -106.998 kJ/mol, respectively. It is obvious that the adsorption energy is less than that on the 2 × 1 surface but still more than that on 1 × 1 surface. It means that the proper Ce doping, (such as forming a 2 × 1 model), can promote the adsorption of NH3, but a large amount of Ce doping, (such as forming a 1 × 1 model), can inhibit it. This is consistent with the experimental results that the highest SCR of NO removal efficiency can be obtained under the optimal Ce doping for the Fe based catalysts [24]. The adsorption of NO on Ce γ-Fe2O3 doping surface The NO can be adsorbed on Ce doped γ-Fe2O3 catalyst surface. Due to the fact that the surface Fe coordination number is not saturated, NO atoms can be accommodated. The N atom and O atom can be bonded with Fe cation. The adsorption energies of the two configurations are -251.276 kJ/mol and -133.549 kJ/mol, respectively. In the process of NO adsorption, some electrons are transferred from NO molecule to the substrate due to the fact that the Mulliken charges are 0.314 and 0.096 for the two configurations, forming a stable chemical bond between the NO molecule and the octahedral Fe on the surface. The dope of Ce can also impact the adsorption of NO on the surface. Fig. 9 shows the configuration of NO adsorption. Fig. 9(a), (b), (c), (d) show the N-Ce, O-Ce, N-Fe, and O-Fe configurations and the optimized parameters are listed on Table 3 . respectively In the process of NO adsorption, the N and O atoms can bind with metal cation. The results show that the adsorption energy is generally increased compared with that of the surface without doping. The adsorption capacity of NO in Fe cation is stronger than that in Ce, thus the bond between NO and Fe is more stable. Besides, NO molecule is more inclined to the link between N and metal cations. The Mulliken charge results show that in the process of NO adsorption, electrons transfer from the substrate to the NO molecule, which is different from the without doped case. This is because the doping of Ce introduces a large number of free electrons. Therefore, the Fermi energy level moves to the high energy level, and more electrons enter the hybrid orbit formed by NO and the surface. In order to reveal the adsorption mechanism, the PDOS of adsorption process was analyzed which is shown in Fig. 10 . Fig. 10(a), (b) show the PDOS of configuration of the adsorption of NO on Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface. It can be seen that the p orbital of NO overlap with the f orbital of Ce is around the Fermi energy level in Fig. 10(b), which means that the chemical bonds formed between N atom and Ce cation. But the p orbital of NO and d orbital of Fe cation are overlap in −2 eV, -0.5 eV and 1 eV in Fig. 10(a), which means the N atom resonates strongly with the iron ion and hybridizes into bonds. These results show the doping with Ce on γ-Fe2O3 can promote the adsorption of NO molecule. To study the influence of concentration of Ce, the adsorption of NO on Ce doping 2 × 1 surface was studied and shown in Fig. 11 , and the adsorption energy is listed in Table 4 . Table 4 shows the adsorption energy for the adsorption of NO with the N atom and O atom close to the metal cation. It can be seen that the adsorption energy is larger than that in 1 × 1 Ce doping surface no matter what configuration. Accordingly, the doping of Ce can improve the adsorption of NO but excessive doping can inhibit the process. Therefore, combined with the adsorption of NH3, it can be concluded that the 2 × 1 doping surface is the optimum surface that can promote the adsorption of NH3 and NO largely in the SCR process. It is one of reasons of the experiment result that the doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3 surface can improve the SCR NOx removal efficiency but excessive Ce may reduce the efficiency [24]. The SCR reaction on Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface in anaerobic condition O2 makes an important effect in SCR process. With or without O2, therefore, the result of the SCR reaction is different. In order to fully reflect the role of O2, this section considers the SCR reaction in the absence of oxygen firstly. On the other hand, the 3.3 section analyzed the adsorption under different Ce doping concentrations. It is obtained that the maximum adsorption energy belongs to the 2 × 1 surface and which can be regarded as the optimal adsorption condition. Therefore, the 2 × 1 surface is selected to discuss the SCR reaction on Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface without O2 existed. Additionally, On the 2 × 1 surface, there are three active sites of iron ions, Fe1, Fe2, and Fe3. Due to the shortest distance between Fe1 and Ce, the catalytic activity of Fe1 and Fe2 (Fe3) is quite different. Therefore, this section will discuss the SCR reaction at the active site of Fe1 and that of Fe2(Fe3), respectively. The NH3 dehydrogenation reaction on Fe2 site Fig. 12 shows NH3 dehydrogenation reaction over Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 catalyst. In the process, the NH3 was firstly absorbed on the Fe2 site. Then, the adsorbed NH3 molecule can be oxidized on the condition of lattice oxygen and lose one H atom and produce NH2. The reaction heat is 65.264 kJ/mol while the activation energy barrier is 82.604 kJ/mol. On the other hand, the reaction heat is 71.644 kJ/mol and the activation energy barrier is 88.040 kJ/mol on the undoped γ-Fe2O3 surface. It is obviously that both the reaction heat and energy barrier decrease in the condition of Ce doping. This is because the addition of Ce will lead to dislocation deformation of the crystal lattice on the catalyst surface, which will lead to a shorter distance between lattice oxygen and H atom and thus an easier dehydrogenation. Moreover, the addition of Ce will bring more valence electrons to the surface of the catalyst, which will increase the density of electrons near the surface lattice oxygen and make it easier to bond with H atom. It can be seen that the addition of Ce is indeed conducive to the dehydrogenation of NH3, thus forming more intermediate products of NH2. Next, the NH2 fragment can continue to be oxidized to form NH. The corresponding energy barrier is 121.640 kJ/mol, on the undoped surface, the energy barrier is 108.464 kJ/mol. It can be seen, although the reaction heat reduced, the activation energy barrier has increased, which means that the doping of Ce makes the reaction more difficult. Besides, the NH can lose H continually and only left N atom left. The reaction heat is 43.848 kJ/mol while the activation energy barrier is 98.810 kJ/mol. On the other hand, on the undoped surface, the reaction heat is -45.852 kJ/mol and the activation energy barrier is 55.592 kJ/mol. The reaction heat and activation energy barrier improve dramatically, which means the reaction is hard to take place. Therefore, the results show that the addition of Ce can inhibit the formation of N on the surface, thus reducing the formation of N2O. Accordingly, the reaction path shows that the activation energy barrier of formation of NH2 fragment step is lowest, and the formation of NH is hard to go and it is consistent to experiment results. Fig. 13 shows the formation of NH2NO. In this process, radical NH2 with N-Fe bond is still bonded on Fe cation of Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 catalyst. When a NO molecule closes to the bond NH2 radical, the O atom bond to the another Fe site and the N atom of NO connect with N of NH2. The activation energy barrier is 17.648 kJ/mol, it is small which means that the process easily produces. The reaction process is similar to on the undoping surface, it is still a fast reaction. The decomposition of NH2NO on Fe2 site Fig. 14 shows the decomposition process of NH2NO after its formation. First, due to the attraction of lattice oxygen, NH2NO will lose one H atom, the activation energy is 23.780 kJ/mol, and the reaction heat is -103.332 kJ/mol. And that means that this process is easy to occur. During this reaction, some energy was released and NHNO was formed. Then, the chemical bond between N and O is broken, and the last H ion falls off from the remaining NHN fragment, and then attracted by the O atom to generate an OH hydroxyl group. After the leaving of H ion, the remaining fragment becomes an adsorbed N2 molecule. The activation energy is 60.258 kJ/mol. Although the activation energy is relatively high, a large amount of heat is released during the reaction of the previous step to compensate. This means the process is also relatively easy to occur and release a lot of energy. In the last step, OH can react with the H on the surface to produce the final product H2O. The activation energy barrier is 46.597 kJ/mol while the reaction heat is only 1.396 kJ/mol. Since the activation energy at this step is small, this process is also fast. The decomposition process of NH2NO generates the N2 and H2O and the main process of SCR reaction is completed. However, there is still one H atom linked with O ion on the surface, which needs O2 oxidation. The NH3 dehydrogenation reaction on the Fe1 site The reaction mentioned above is only related to the situation of NH3 adsorbed to the Fe2 cation. There are three different Fe cations on the Ce-doped γFe2O3 catalyst 2 × 1(001) surface. The distances between Fe2 and Fe3 and Ce are almost the same and have similar properties. However, the property of Fe1 is different from Fe2 and Fe3, so it is necessary to study the reaction pathway of NH3 adsorbed on Fe1 individually. Fig. 15 shows the NH3 dehydrogenation reaction at the Fe1 position. Compared with Fe2 and Fe3, the reaction pathways of Fe1 and Ce are almost the same. The only difference is the reaction heat and activation energy barrier. NH3 is first absorbed on Fe1. Then, an H atom of adsorbed NH3 is lost to produce NH2, and the reaction heat is 42.244 kJ/mol, while the activation energy barrier is -15.744 kJ/mol. The activation energy of the dehydrogenation reaction in this step is greatly reduced compared with the previous one, indicating that the process of dehydrogenation of NH3 near Ce to generate NH2 is easier. This is due to Ce doping, introducing a large number of valence electrons, resulting in enhanced oxidizability of lattice oxygen. Then, NH2 continues to lose H to generate NH, the activation energy barrier could reach 166.600 kJ/mol while the reaction heat is 76.580 kJ/mol. This step has a high activation energy, therefore, the formation of NH in this reaction is a very difficult process. Then, NH can also be continuously oxidized by lattice oxygen, leaving only one N ion on the iron cation. The energy barrier is 32.840 kJ/mol while reaction heat is 24.059 kJ/mol. It shows the adsorption reaction path of NH3 on the Fe1 position and the Fe2 (Fe3) position is the same, but the energy barrier of each step is different, and the activation energies of the steps of forming NH fragment is very high, making NH fragment and N anion difficult to form. Therefore, similar to the former reaction, the NH3 dehydrogenation reaction mainly generates NH2 radicals, and this step is easier to perform than on the undoped surface, so the addition of Ce can promote the dehydrogenation reaction of the adsorbed NH3 on the catalyst surface. The reaction after NH2 generated on the Fe1 site Fig. 16 shows the reaction process after NH2 is generated on the Fe1 cation of the catalyst surface. It can be seen that after the generation of NH2, it can directly react with the NO molecules adsorbed on Ce cation to generate N2 and H2O. But the activation energy of this step is high, reaching 123.558 kJ/mol. Hence the subsequent direct reaction of NH2 and NO is more difficult to complete when NH3 adsorbed on Fe1 cation. Since the distance between Fe1 and Ce is shortest, the excess doping of Ce will cause more Fe1 cations to appear, which takes disadvantage to the SCR reaction. On the other hand, when there are two adjacent surface Fe on the catalyst surface, according to the previous analysis, adsorbed NH2 can react with NO adsorbed on the adjacent other Fe cations to generate NH2NO on its surface and then decompose into N2 and H2O. This reaction is easy to proceed with. However, if Ce is added too much, it will occupy the octahedral iron active site on the surface, hinder this reaction to take place and thereby reducing SCR NOx removal efficiency, which is demonstrated by the experimental results [24]. The SCR reaction on Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface under the aerobic condition The decomposition of O2 on metal cation As mentioned above, O2 as an important reactant makes a significant effect on the SCR process. Since the coordination number of the metal cation is unsaturated, two O atoms can combine with the metal cation to form a stable chemical bond when O2 is adsorbed. The adsorption structure is shown in Fig. 17 . In Fig. 17(a), two O atoms are connected to Fe active site, and in Fig. 17(b) configuration, one O atom is connected to Ce and another to Fe. The adsorption energies of these two configurations are -686.763 kJ/mol and -665.947 kJ/mol, which means that a large amount of energy is released. Compared with the adsorption energy is -531.173 kJ/mol on undoped surface, it shows that due to the doping of Ce, the adsorption energy of oxygen is significantly increased. This is because the doping of Ce will introduce more valence electrons, and more free electrons will enter the blend bonding orbital, making O2 is easier adsorbed on the catalyst surface. After adsorption, O2 will decompose into two active O anions. Fig. 17 shows the decomposition process after O2 adsorption. It can be seen that after adsorption, O2 will decompose into two active oxygen anions. The activation energies of these two configurations are 77.504 kJ/mol and 105.928 kJ/mol, respectively. Compared with undoped surface, the activation energy of the first configuration (Fig. 17(a)) is reduced, which shows that the O2 of the first configuration dissociates on the doped surface more easily. The activation energy of the second configuration (Fig. 17(b)) is increased. However, during the O2 adsorption process, the Ce doped surface releases more energy than on the undoped surface, which is enough to compensate for the energy barrier raised at this step. Therefore, Ce doping can promote the process of O2 adsorption and dissociation on the catalyst surface. The dehydrogenation of adsorbed NH3 under the effect of adsorbed O anion After dissociation, two active oxygen anions will react with NH3 to produce NH2, and NH. The reaction processes are shown in Figs. 18 and 19 . Fig. 18(a) shows the dehydrogenation of adsorbed NH3 to form NH2 under the action of active oxygen when the O anion adsorbed on Fe cation and Fig. 18(b) shows that when the O anion adsorbed on Ce cation. It can be seen from the figure that the activation energies of the two configurations are 43.688 kJ/mol and 25.244 kJ/mol, respectively. That is to say, the activation energy of dehydrogenation of adsorbed NH3 when it is affected by the O anion adsorbed on Ce, is significantly lower than that on the undoped surface, as shown in Fig. 18(b). This is because O anion adsorbed on Ce cation attracts a large number of electrons in the surface adsorption process due to the larger atomic radius of Ce, resulting in enhanced oxidability, and thus easy to react with the adsorbed NH3. On the other hand, the activation energy of that affected by the O anion adsorbed on Fe, is slightly lower than the undoped surface, which should be resulted also from affected by Fe ions, and with little change as shown in Fig. 18(a). Nevertheless, the activation energies of this step for both situations are all lower than that of undoped γ-Fe2O3 catalyst and lower than that without the effects of the activated O anion. The reaction after NH2 generation under the effect of adsorbed O anion After NH2 is generated, it will react with NO to generate NH2NO under the action of surface catalyst, and then the intermediate product NH2NO will decompose to produce N2 and H2O. From the previous analysis, we can see that the process of NH2NO generation and decomposition is a fast process. However, if there is an active oxygen existed next to generated NH2, it will continue to be oxidized and dehydrogenated to generate NH, as shown in Fig. 19(a) and (b). It can be seen that the activation energies of the two reactions are 48.412 kJ/mol and 78.564 kJ/mol. It indicates that the activation energies of the two reactions are not large, reflecting that the reactions in this step are relatively easy to carry out, and the activation energy of Fig. 19(b) configuration is much greater than that of the Fig. 19(a). When NH is generated, it will continue to react with NO to form NHNO, and then it could decompose, the process is shown in Figs. 20 and 21 . Fig. 20 shows the NHNO generation process. After NH is generated, it will react with adsorbed NO to generate NHNO. The activation energy is 8.480 kJ/mol, while a large amount of energy will be released as NHNO is generated. The activation energy of the NHNO generation is very small and the process is a rapid SCR reaction process. Fig. 21 shows the decomposition of NHNO. The activation energy is 23.720 kJ/mol, and it is also very low. Therefore, the formation and decomposition of NHNO on the catalyst surface is a rapid reaction process. The reaction to generate NO2 under the effect of adsorbed O anion In the SCR reaction, when active oxygen is present on the surface, it will also react with the adsorbed NO to generate NO2. As shown in Fig. 22 . Fig. 22(a) and (b) show the NO2 generation process when NO is adsorbed on Fe cation or Ce cation, respectively. It can be seen from the figures that the active O will react with the adsorbed NO to generate NO2. The activation energies are 2.533 kJ/mol and 33.780 kJ/mol. It is obvious that the activation energies of these two steps are low, so they are easy to carry out. Moreover, the activation energy of the configuration shown by Fig. 22(a) is much lower than that shown by Fig. 22(b), indicating that the synergistic effect of the octahedral iron on the two surfaces is stronger than that between Ce-Fe. The NO2 could generate NO3 − in γFe2O3 catalyst (001) surface, and then, it could form NH4NO3 easily [44]. It is reported that NH4NO3 is not stable enough that could be reduced by NO above 170℃. On the surface of the catalyst, it will be reduced to NH4NO2, and then the intermediate product will decompose into N2 and H2O at about 100℃. The reaction steps are [45–47]. N H 4 N O 3 + N O ↔ N H 4 N O 2 + N O 2 N H 4 N O 2 → N 2 +2 H 2 O The formation and decomposition of NH4NO2 is particularly easy to carry out, therefore, the presence of ammonium nitrate is conducive to the catalytic reaction. Thus, NO2 generation belongs to the fast SCR reaction process in the SCR reaction. The formation of NO2 means that the SCR reaction can be transferred to the low temperature direction. Therefore, the addition of Ce can promote the process of SCR reaction. Comparison of the SCR reactions under different conditions Fig. 23 shows a skeletal reaction scheme in the SCR process over Ce doped-γFe2O3 catalyst. On the Ce and Fe1 sites, the NH3 could adsorption and then dehydrogenate to produce NH2, which could react with NO to form N2 and H2O. The activation energy of the former step is low, it is only 42.688 kJ/mol, but the latter is high which could reach 123.558 kJ/mol. This shows the Ce itself as active site could participate the reaction. On the Fe2 (or Fe3) active sites, the NH3 dehydrogenate to form NH2, and then the NH2 radical reacts with NO and form NH2NO, then it can decompose into N2 and H2O. In the whole reaction pathway, the rate determining step is the NH3 dehydrogenation and the activation energy barrier is 82.604 kJ/mol on anaerobic condition. Compared with pristine surfaces, appropriate doping can promote the adsorption of reactants on the surface, while excessive doping will inhibit the adsorption process, and the reaction process is basically unchanged, but the difficulty degree of each step changes. On the Fe2 (or Fe3) active sites, the active energy barrier of NH3 dehydrogenation is lower which means the step is easier to produce. On aerobic condition, the doping of O2 could promote the adsorption of O2, and the O2 could participate in and promote the SCR reaction process. The presence of oxygen will greatly reduce the activation energy required for NH3 dehydrogenation, thus promoting SCR reaction process. On the Ce and Fe1 sites, some changes have taken place in the reaction process. The first step is still the process of NH3 dehydrogenation, and the presence of Ce will reduce the activation energy of this step. It is only 43.688 kJ/mol. In the second step, NH2 will directly react with NO to produce N2 and H2O, and the second step has higher activation energy, which indicates that this step is not easy to carry out. Since the reaction related to the Fe1 is occurred in the situation of high concentration of the Ce doping, this result shows that an appropriate amount of Ce doping can promote the SCR reaction, while excessive Ce doping will inhibit the SCR reaction. Meanwhile, the NO2 mechanism also exists. The active O can react with absorbed NO form NO2 easily since the energy barrier is 2.533 kJ/mol. It is a fast SCR process and obeys the l-H mechanism. Conclusion 1 Ce can form stable composite oxides on the surface of γ-Fe2O3 catalyst. The doping of Ce will bring more valence electrons to the catalyst surface, and a large number of electrons will be transferred from Ce to Fe. Besides, since the diameter of the Ce cation is larger than that of Fe cation, the doping of Ce can cause the dislocation of the γ-Fe2O3 surface lattice, thus changing the redox ability of the surface. 2 The adsorption energy of NH3 increases with the increase of Ce doping at first, however excessive Ce doping will reduce the adsorption NH3. The adsorption capacity of NO can also increase after the doping of Ce. Hence, the maximum adsorption will be obtained in the optimal doping amount. 3 In anaerobic SCR reaction, on the Fe2 (or Fe3) sites, NH3 is adsorbed first, and then dehydrogenation form NH2 with the condition of lattice oxygen, and react with NO to form NH2NO, finally, NH2NO decomposed into N2 and H2O with low activation energy barrier. The activation energy of NH3 dehydrogenation to NH2 is the highest in total SCR reaction. Therefore, the NH3 dehydrogenation is the rate determining step of reaction rate. But the energy barrier is still lower than that on the undoped surface, which means the doping of Ce can promote the SCR process. On the Fe1(or Ce) sites, on the other hand, the dehydrogenation of NH3 is easier to perform, but the subsequent reaction will be performed with a high activation energy barrier. It means that the appropriate of Ce doping can promote the SCR reaction, while excessive Ce doping will inhibit the SCR reaction. 4 Under the aerobic condition, the oxygen molecules dissociate two active O on the Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface. The H atom in the adsorbed NH3 is attracted by the nearest active oxygen anion to form the hydroxyl group and makes NH3 become NH2 radical. In aerobic condition, besides, the activation energy barrier of NH2 is lower than that of anaerobic condition, which means that the absorbed NH3 is more likely to react with active O in the presence of O2, and that is also lower than that on the undoped γ-Fe2O3 surface and shows the good effects of Ce doping. 5 There is NO molecular adsorption on the Ce doping γ-Fe2O3 surface of catalyst. On aerobic condition, the NO reacts with surface active O to form NO2. The activation energy barrier is very low, and NO2 is easy to form. And then, it could take part in the rapid SCR reaction. Hence, Ce doping can reduce the activation energy of NO2 formation and promote the development of SCR process. coredata.dc:description: The doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3 catalyst surface can improve the NO removal catalytic activity and widen the temperature window of activity. However, the mechanism of promoting the De-NOx activity of γ-Fe2O3 catalyst by Ce doping has not been revealed. In this paper, therefore, the doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3(001) surface and the adsorption behavior of NH3 and NO as well as the reaction pathway were studied by the density functional theory (DFT). The results show that the doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3(001) surface can lead to the migration of electrons on the surface of catalyst and cause the dislocation of the surface lattice, so as to improve the surface acid activity. Thus, the Ce doping can increase the adsorbed energy of the modified γ-Fe2O3 catalyst to NO and NH3 and decrease the activation energy barrier of the rate determining step in SCR reaction. Furthermore, the effects of Ce doping will change with the concentration of the Ce doping, and the excellent SCR De-NOx efficiency will be obtained in the optimal doping amount. On the other hand, O2 makes an important effect. Which makes the activation energy barrier of the rate determining step under aerobic condition lower than that under anaerobic conditions, causes the surface active O to react with NO to form NO2 and perform a rapid SCR reaction. The Ce doping can promote the dissociation of O2 on the active cation site and reduce the activation energy barriers of above steps. Accordingly, the doping of Ce on γ-Fe2O3 catalyst surface can improve the SCR process.
coredata.dc:title: Quantum chemistry study of SCR-NH3 nitric oxide reduction on Ce-doped γFe2O3 catalyst surface
